text: is there a better way to convert a list to a dictionary in python with keys but no values?
I was sure that there would be a one liner to convert a list to a dictionary where the items in the list were keys and the dictionary had no values.
The only way I could find to do it was argued against
"Using list comprehensions when the result is ignored is misleading and inefficient.

code:
myList=['a','b','c','d']
myDict={}
x=[myDict.update({item:None}) for item in myList]

>>> myDict
{'a': None, 'c': None, 'b': None, 'd': None}

text: It works but I thought someone might have some insight as to a better way to do this.
